'''Pauline Betz Addie''' (née '''Pauline May Betz''', August 6, 1919 – May 31, 2011) was an American professional [[tennis]] player.
She won five [[Grand Slam title|Grand Slam]] singles titles and was the runner-up on three other occasions. [[Jack Kramer (tennis player)|Jack Kramer]] has called her the second best female tennis player he ever saw, behind [[Helen Wills|Helen Wills Moody]].<ref>[http://tennis.quickfound.net/history/jack_kramer.html Female players & the 1950–51 Pauline Betz-Gussy Moran tour]</ref>

==Early life==
Betz attended [[Los Angeles High School]] and learned her tennis from [[Dick Skeen]]. She continued her tennis and education at [[Rollins College]] (graduating in 1943),<ref name=PaulineBetzWM>{{cite web|url=http://web.wm.edu/tenniscenter/addie.html|title=ITA Women's Hall of Fame...|publisher=ITA Women's Hall of Fame McCormack-Nagelsen Tennis Center, William & Mary College|accessdate=October 6, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823121729/http://web.wm.edu/tenniscenter/addie.html|archivedate=August 23, 2010}}</ref><ref name=RollinsAthleticHallofFame>{{cite web|url=http://tars.rollins.edu/athletics/tradition/index.shtml|title=Rollins College Athletics Hall of Fame|publisher=Rollins College Athletics Department|accessdate=October 6, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528013210/http://tars.rollins.edu/athletics/tradition/index.shtml|archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name=SportsThen&Now>{{cite web|url=http://sportsthenandnow.com/2009/08/25/rollins-college-womens-tennis-the-small-school-with-the-big-tradition/|title=Rollins College Women's Tennis: Small School With A Big Tradition|publisher=Sports Then and Now|accessdate=October 6, 2010}}</ref><ref name=RollinsSportsWTennisTradition>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollinssports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=19500&ATCLID=1547225|title=Tennis-Women's: Tradition|publisher=Rollins College Athletics Department|accessdate=October 6, 2010|url-status=dead|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715200513/http://www.rollinssports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=19500&ATCLID=1547225|archivedate=July 15, 2011}}</ref> where she was a member of [[Kappa Alpha Theta]] sorority. Betz earned an MA in economics from [[Columbia University]].<ref name="itahof"/><ref name="bde1943">{{cite news|author1=Harold Parrott|title=Hunt, blocked by Riggs, emulates dad as champion|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/52663928/|work=[[The Brooklyn Daily Eagle]]|date=September 7, 1943|page=11|via=[[Newspapers.com]]|url-access=subscription }}</ref>

==Career==
Betz won the first of her four singles titles at the [[US Open (tennis)|U.S. Championships]] in 1942, saving a match point in the semifinals against [[Margaret Osborne duPont|Margaret Osborne]] while trailing 3–5 in the final set.<ref name=tennisfame>[https://www.tennisfame.com/hall-of-famers/inductees/pauline-betz-addie/ Pauline May Betz profile (Addie)], tennisfame.com; accessed November 25, 2016.</ref>  The following year, she won the [[Western & Southern Financial Group Women's Open|Tri-State tournament]] in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]], defeating [[Catherine Wolf]] in the final 6–0, 6–2 without losing a point in the first set,<ref name=tennisfame/> a "[[golden set]]". She won the [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon]] singles title in 1946, the only time she entered the tournament, without losing a set.<ref name=tennisfame/> At the [[1946 French Championships (tennis)|1946 French Championships]], held that year after Wimbledon, she lost the final in three sets to Margaret Osborne after failing to convert two match points.<ref name="collins"/>

Her amateur career ended in 1947 when the [[USTA|USLTA]] revoked her amateur status for exploring the possibilities of turning professional.<ref name=tennisfame/><ref name="telegraphobituary">{{cite web|title=Pauline Betz|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/sport-obituaries/8558165/Pauline-Betz.html|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=June 5, 2011}}</ref><ref name="guardian">{{cite web|author1=Richard Evans|title=Pauline Betz obituary|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2011/jun/20/pauline-betz-obituary|publisher=[[The Guardian]]|date=20 June 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Betz undecided on future plans|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sFAsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=E8sEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3688%2C840068|work=[[Spartanburg Herald-Journal]]|agency=AP|date=April 10, 1947|page=13}}</ref> Betz played two professional tours of matches against [[Sarah Palfrey Cooke]] (1947) and [[Gussie Moran]] (1951).<ref name="collins"/>

According to [[John Olliff]] of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' and ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', Addie was ranked World No. 1 in 1946 (no rankings issued from 1940 through 1945).<ref name="collins">{{cite book|last=Collins|first=Bud|authorlink=Bud Collins|title=The Bud Collins History of Tennis: An Authoritative Encyclopedia and Record Book|publisher=New Chapter Press|location=New York|year=2008|pages=695, 702|isbn=978-0-942257-41-0}}</ref> She was included in the year-end top ten rankings issued by the [[United States Tennis Association|United States Lawn Tennis Association]] from 1939 through 1946.  She was the top ranked U.S. player from 1942 through 1944 and in 1946.<ref>{{cite book |author=United States Tennis Association |title=1988 Official USTA Tennis Yearbook |publisher=H.O. Zimman, Inc. |location=Lynn, Massachusetts |year=1988 |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |accessdate= |pages=260–1}}</ref>

===Awards and honors===

On September 2, 1946 Betz appeared on the cover of [[TIME magazine|''TIME'' magazine]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Pauline Betz|url=http://content.time.com/time/covers/0,16641,19460902,00.html|work=[[TIME (magazine)|TIME]]}}</ref><ref name="independent"/>
Betz was inducted into the [[International Tennis Hall of Fame]] in 1965.<ref name=tennisfame/> In 1995 she was inducted in the ITA Women's Collegiate Tennis Hall of Fame.<ref name="itahof">{{cite web|title=Pauline Betz Addie|url=http://itahalloffame.org/inductees/pauline-betz-addie/|publisher=[[Intercollegiate Tennis Association ]] (ITA)}}</ref> The Pauline Betz Addie Tennis Center at Cabin John Regional Park in [[Potomac, Maryland]] was renamed in her honor on May 1, 2008.  Addie, [[Albert "Allie" Ritzenberg|Albert Ritzenberg]], and Stanly Hoffberger founded the center in 1972.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://classic.sidwell.edu/retired_former_employees/archives/Addie.htm |title=Pauline Betz Addie |publisher=Sidwell Friends School |accessdate=April 10, 2016 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304035007/http://classic.sidwell.edu/retired_former_employees/archives/Addie.htm |archivedate=March 4, 2016 }}</ref>

==Personal life==

In 1949 Betz published an autobiography titled ''Wings on my Tennis Shoes''.<ref>{{cite book|title=Wings on my tennis shoes|publisher=[[Worldcat]]|oclc=717317192}}</ref><ref name="independent">{{cite web|author1=Martin Childs|title=Pauline Betz: Grand slam-winning tennis player banned for merely considering turning professional|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/pauline-betz-grand-slam-winning-tennis-player-banned-for-merely-considering-turning-professional-2298746.html|publisher=[[The Independent]]|date=June 17, 2011}}</ref> That same year she married [[Bob Addie]], a [[sportswriter]] for the ''[[Washington Times-Herald]]'' and ''[[Washington Post]]''.<ref name=nyt2011/><ref name=tennisfame/> The couple had five children, including poet and [[novelist]] [[Kim Addonizio]], Rusty, Gary, Jon and Rick.<ref name=nyt2011/><ref name="guardian"/> Her granddaughter [[Aya Cash]] is an actress. Pauline Betz Addie died in her sleep on May 31, 2011, aged 91.<ref name=nyt2011>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/03/sports/tennis/pauline-betz-addie-a-dominant-tennis-champion-dies-at-91.html?ref=deathsobituaries|title=Pauline Betz Addie, a Dominant Tennis Champion, Dies at 91|author=Robin Finn|date=June 2, 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
